content.text:
Why is the sky blue?

And tall?

content.thinking: The user is asking general knowledge questions, not coding-related ones. I'll answer directly.

content.text:
## Why is the sky blue?

The sky appears blue due to **Rayleigh scattering**. When sunlight enters Earth's atmosphere, it collides with gas molecules (mostly nitrogen and oxygen). Sunlight contains all colors of the visible spectrum, but shorter wavelengths (blue/violet) are scattered much more strongly than longer wavelengths (red/orange). Blue light is scattered in all directions across the sky, which is why we see it as blue when we look up.

(Violet is actually scattered even more than blue, but our eyes are more sensitive to blue, and some violet is absorbed in the upper atmosphere — so we perceive the sky as blue rather than violet.)

## And tall?

The atmosphere extends roughly **100 km (62 miles)** above Earth's surface (the Kármán line), though there's no sharp boundary — it gradually thins out. The visible blue sky effect mostly comes from the lower ~10-50 km of atmosphere where the air is dense enough for significant scattering. So in that sense, the sky is "tall" because Earth has a substantial gaseous atmosphere held in place by gravity.

The ocean is deep due to a combination of geological processes over billions of years:

## Plate Tectonics
The ocean floor is shaped by the movement of tectonic plates. At **mid-ocean ridges**, new crust forms and pushes outward. As oceanic crust moves away from ridges, it cools, becomes denser, and **sinks lower** — creating deeper basins. At **subduction zones**, one plate dives beneath another, carving deep trenches (like the Mariana Trench at ~11 km / 36,000 ft).

## Water Volume
Earth has a *lot* of water — roughly **1.335 billion cubic kilometers**. This massive volume, accumulated over billions of years (from volcanic outgassing, cometary impacts, etc.), fills and overflows the basins created by tectonics.

## Gravity & Density
Oceanic crust is made of **basalt**, which is denser than the **granite** of continental crust. Denser oceanic crust sits lower on the mantle (isostasy), naturally forming deep basins relative to the continents.

## Key Numbers
| Feature | Depth |
|---|---|
| Average ocean depth | ~3.7 km (2.3 mi) |
| Deepest point (Challenger Deep) | ~11 km (6.8 mi) |

So in short: geology carved the basins, and Earth had more than enough water to fill them.
